scenario: You must select a software vendor for a critical system upgrade with limited time for evaluation.

options.text: Compare key performance data quickly and choose the most reliable vendor.
Hold a long discussion with every stakeholder before deciding.
Delegate the choice to a senior team member familiar with vendors.
Pick the lowest-cost option to save budget.

scenario: A sudden system failure threatens to delay delivery. You must act before full details are known.

options.text: Make the best decision using available facts and update once verified.
Pause all work until a full root-cause analysis is complete.
Ask the team to continue while you gather more information.
Escalate the issue immediately to senior management.

scenario: Two promising candidates are equally qualified for a key position.

options.text: Re-evaluate both using objective performance indicators.
Choose the candidate who aligns best with team culture.
Let the team vote on their preferred candidate.
Delay the hiring until more data or feedback arrives.

scenario: Your project budget was unexpectedly reduced by 30%.

options.text: Reprioritize deliverables to focus on high-impact outcomes.
Request more funds while continuing with the original plan.
Cut non-essential features immediately without consultation.
Freeze the project until finances are clarified.

scenario: Two team leads disagree about which task should be prioritized first.

options.text: Analyze impact and decide based on organizational goals.
Ask both to compromise and split resources evenly.
Allow them to decide independently.
Delay decision until more data is available.

scenario: A client requests a change that will extend the project timeline.

options.text: Negotiate scope and adjust schedule realistically.
Accept without negotiation to maintain goodwill.
Reject the request immediately to protect timeline.
Defer the decision to your manager.

scenario: You must choose between two suppliers: one cheaper but less proven, the other costlier but reliable.

options.text: Select the reliable supplier based on risk analysis.
Pick the cheaper one to stay within budget.
Ask the team for input before choosing.
Delay purchase until next quarter.

scenario: A sudden market trend challenges your current business strategy.

options.text: Review data quickly and pivot strategy if justified.
Wait to see if the trend stabilizes before acting.
Continue the current plan but communicate awareness.
Let upper management decide the next move.

scenario: Your team proposes two equally good technical solutions.

options.text: Compare long-term scalability and maintenance cost before deciding.
Pick the most innovative one to motivate the team.
Let the team vote to encourage ownership.
Randomly choose to save time.

scenario: A senior executive insists on a course of action you believe is risky.

options.text: Present data-driven evidence and propose safer alternatives.
Follow orders while documenting your concerns.
Comply without objection to avoid conflict.
Escalate the disagreement to HR or another leader.

scenario: Your department must cut 10% of its workforce.

options.text: Use objective performance data to make the decision fairly.
Consult team leads for recommendations.
Choose randomly to avoid personal bias.
Ask HR to make all termination decisions.

scenario: You discover an error in a financial report already sent to a client.

options.text: Inform the client immediately with a corrected version.
Quietly fix the record and hope they don't notice.
Inform your manager and wait for instructions.
Blame the error on the accounting software.

scenario: You must allocate limited training funds among multiple teams.

options.text: Fund programs with the highest ROI on performance.
Distribute funds equally to avoid conflict.
Ask department heads to submit proposals.
Postpone spending until next budget cycle.

scenario: Your team disagrees with your proposed project plan.

options.text: Review their feedback and refine your plan based on evidence.
Stick to your plan firmly to show leadership.
Abandon your plan completely to maintain harmony.
Escalate disagreement to your supervisor.

scenario: You’re offered two projects: one safe but routine, another risky but innovative.

options.text: Choose the innovative project with risk mitigation steps.
Pick the safe project to guarantee success.
Ask management which project benefits them more.
Avoid deciding until more data emerges.

scenario: A senior colleague asks you to approve an expense that breaks company policy.

options.text: Decline politely and report through the proper channel.
Approve it quietly to preserve the relationship.
Discuss alternatives that meet both needs ethically.
Ignore it and hope finance notices the violation.

scenario: Data from two analytics tools contradict each other before a major report.

options.text: Investigate discrepancies and triangulate reliable data.
Choose whichever data favors your department.
Delay the report until alignment is achieved.
Disclose both sets of data transparently.

scenario: A cross-functional team asks for your input on a process redesign you know little about.

options.text: Gather quick insights from experts before deciding.
Decline involvement to avoid slowing progress.
Ask for a summary presentation to make an informed call.
Agree to whatever the majority suggests.

scenario: A new technology could automate 40% of your team’s work but may cause layoffs.

options.text: Evaluate both productivity gain and human impact objectively.
Adopt immediately to impress executives.
Reject to protect current employees.
Delay implementation until policy guidelines are clear.

scenario: You must decide whether to cancel a project that’s behind schedule but near completion.

options.text: Assess recovery cost versus value before final decision.
Continue to completion to avoid sunk-cost criticism.
Cancel immediately to focus on new initiatives.
Seek stakeholder input and delay closure decision.

scenario: A team member seems distracted and their performance has dropped recently.

options.text: Have a private talk to understand possible personal or work issues.
Send them a formal email highlighting poor performance.
Ignore the issue until results worsen further.
Reassign them temporarily to easier tasks.

scenario: A junior colleague struggles to explain their idea in a meeting and gets interrupted.

options.text: Invite them to finish speaking and support their idea constructively.
Step in and present their idea on their behalf.
Move on to the next agenda item to save time.
Criticize their communication to push them to improve.

scenario: A team conflict arises due to a misinterpreted message you sent.

options.text: Clarify the intent and apologize for any misunderstanding.
Defend your message and explain that they overreacted.
Ignore it, assuming they will resolve it on their own.
Ask a mediator to handle the clarification for you.

scenario: A remote team member often misses meetings due to time zone differences.

options.text: Adjust meeting times occasionally to include them.
Ask them to catch up from recordings only.
Keep schedule unchanged; consistency is more important.
Remove them from meetings altogether.

scenario: A colleague becomes defensive after receiving constructive feedback.

options.text: Stay calm and restate feedback focusing on solutions.
End the conversation immediately.
Criticize them for being unprofessional.
Ask another team member to deliver the feedback instead.

scenario: You must communicate a major organizational change that will unsettle your team.

options.text: Be transparent and emphasize available support systems.
Share minimal details to avoid panic.
Wait until official HR communication is released.
Let rumors spread and address them later.

scenario: A shy intern presents an incomplete report to the team.

options.text: Encourage them publicly for effort and provide private guidance.
Reassign the task to a more experienced employee.
Criticize them in front of others for missing key data.
Ignore it; they will improve with experience.

scenario: During a brainstorming session, quieter members remain silent.

options.text: Invite quieter members to share thoughts directly.
Proceed with ideas from the more vocal team members.
End session early and ask for written suggestions later.
Let group dynamics handle participation naturally.

scenario: A customer sends an angry email about a product issue.

options.text: Acknowledge frustration and promise immediate investigation.
Forward it to the support team without reply.
Send a detailed explanation defending the product.
Ignore the complaint unless they follow up again.

scenario: You must deliver negative feedback to a high-performing employee.

options.text: Balance praise with constructive points and offer coaching.
Be direct about issues without sugarcoating.
Avoid mentioning it to preserve morale.
Send feedback via email instead of a conversation.

scenario: A cross-cultural team struggles with language misunderstandings.

options.text: Encourage open clarification and simplify shared communication tools.
Assign one translator to manage all messages.
Continue as usual; issues will resolve over time.
Exclude members who communicate less fluently.

scenario: A team member disagrees with your decision in front of others.

options.text: Acknowledge their point and invite discussion respectfully.
Defend your decision firmly without discussion.
Dismiss their input to maintain authority.
Ignore the comment entirely.

scenario: You notice a normally vocal team member has become unusually quiet in meetings.

options.text: Check in privately to ensure they feel comfortable sharing.
Ask them in public why they are silent lately.
Ignore it unless it affects deadlines.
Have another colleague talk to them informally.

scenario: Two employees have cultural differences causing tension.

options.text: Mediate by discussing diversity and mutual respect.
Separate them onto different teams.
Let them resolve it privately.
Ignore it unless HR intervenes.

scenario: You must explain a complex idea to non-technical stakeholders.

options.text: Simplify the concept and use relatable examples.
Provide a technical document and let them review.
Ignore misunderstandings; they aren’t your problem.
Ask your technical lead to present instead.

scenario: An employee takes criticism personally and reacts emotionally.

options.text: Allow them time to cool down and follow up with empathy.
Reiterate that emotions shouldn’t affect feedback.
End the discussion abruptly.
Involve HR to manage the reaction.

scenario: A teammate’s mistake causes client dissatisfaction.

options.text: Take accountability as a leader and resolve it collectively.
Blame the teammate privately to ensure lessons are learned.
Address it publicly to demonstrate standards.
Ignore it since the issue is already fixed.

scenario: Your new policy announcement was misunderstood by employees.

options.text: Clarify through an open Q&A session and feedback loop.
Send a clarification email only.
Do nothing; misunderstandings fade with time.
Delegate communication to another department.

scenario: A peer receives credit for an idea you initially proposed.

options.text: Acknowledge the idea publicly and add your contribution respectfully.
Privately confront them for stealing your idea.
Complain to management about unfair recognition.
Stay silent to avoid tension.

scenario: A client keeps asking the same questions despite your previous explanations.

options.text: Remain patient and rephrase answers for clarity.
Remind them firmly that you’ve already explained.
Ignore their follow-up emails.
Escalate the client to another representative.

scenario: Two team members are arguing about how to implement a project feature.

options.text: Bring both together to hear their views and find a compromise.
Decide whose idea to use and move on.
Let them resolve it privately.
Avoid involvement to keep peace.

scenario: A senior colleague publicly criticizes your approach during a team meeting.

options.text: Stay calm, acknowledge their view, and propose a follow-up discussion.
Defend your idea strongly in front of everyone.
Ignore the comment to maintain professionalism.
Confront them after the meeting in frustration.

scenario: A team feels one member isn’t contributing enough to group work.

options.text: Discuss expectations openly and set clear shared goals.
Handle it privately with the underperforming member.
Let the team handle it informally.
Replace the member immediately.

scenario: Two departments are blaming each other for a missed client deadline.

options.text: Hold a joint review to find root causes and lessons learned.
Assign fault to the most responsible team.
Let management decide responsibility.
Avoid addressing the issue to prevent tension.

scenario: You disagree with your manager’s unrealistic deadline.

options.text: Provide evidence and propose a more achievable plan.
Follow orders despite concerns.
Complain about the manager to your peers.
Escalate the issue to upper management.

scenario: Two senior engineers frequently clash over technical decisions.

options.text: Act as mediator to align them on project goals.
Let them sort it out among themselves.
Assign each to different parts of the project.
Pick one side and enforce their approach.

scenario: Your project team is frustrated with unclear roles.

options.text: Clarify roles through an open team discussion.
Assign roles directly and expect compliance.
Ignore the complaints; focus on output.
Ask HR to mediate the issue.

scenario: A team member is dominating discussions, silencing others.

options.text: Privately coach them on inclusive communication.
Confront them during the meeting.
Allow behavior to continue; they contribute value.
Remove them from group meetings.

scenario: Your team is upset because promotions were announced unfairly.

options.text: Listen empathetically and explain the criteria transparently.
Defend the company policy without discussion.
Avoid the discussion; HR will handle it.
Ask employees to stop complaining.

scenario: Two sub-teams blame each other for poor communication on deliverables.

options.text: Create a joint review to establish clear communication rules.
Pick one lead to handle all communication.
Avoid the issue; it will resolve over time.
Blame both teams equally to end the dispute.

scenario: You notice growing tension between two senior managers under you.

options.text: Facilitate a one-on-one dialogue to rebuild trust.
Report the issue to top management.
Reassign them to different teams.
Wait for the issue to resolve naturally.

scenario: A peer ignores your emails and delays collaboration.

options.text: Communicate expectations directly and politely.
Complain to their manager immediately.
Ignore them and move forward without their input.
Send multiple reminders until they reply.

scenario: A client demands a service your team cannot deliver within scope.

options.text: Negotiate respectfully to redefine deliverables.
Promise to deliver and adjust later.
Reject the request immediately.
Ignore the request until escalation occurs.

scenario: Two employees refuse to work together due to personal issues.

options.text: Mediate privately to find a professional resolution.
Assign them to different teams to avoid disruption.
Force them to collaborate regardless.
Ignore the problem unless it escalates.

scenario: Team members feel your feedback style is too harsh.

options.text: Ask for specific feedback and adjust communication style.
Explain that you’re focused on performance, not tone.
Dismiss their concern and continue your style.
Apologize publicly without real change.

scenario: Project partners disagree on the division of funding.

options.text: Review financial data together and align expectations.
Divide funds evenly regardless of effort.
Let leadership make the financial call.
Avoid taking part in financial discussions.

scenario: A stakeholder insists on an unrealistic change mid-project.

options.text: Negotiate scope and timeline adjustments respectfully.
Comply without discussion to maintain the relationship.
Reject the request outright.
Ignore their input completely.

scenario: A high-performing employee frequently undermines others’ opinions.

options.text: Provide direct feedback about collaboration expectations.
Appreciate their performance and overlook the issue.
Address the issue only if complaints arise.
Reassign them to independent tasks.

scenario: An external partner misses multiple deadlines, frustrating your team.

options.text: Discuss delays diplomatically and agree on a recovery plan.
Threaten to cancel the contract immediately.
Ignore the issue and hope improvement occurs.
Escalate the issue to procurement without discussion.

scenario: Two employees argue about unequal workload distribution.

options.text: Review responsibilities and redistribute fairly.
Ask them to balance tasks among themselves.
Ignore the argument until productivity drops.
Assign a new leader to monitor them closely.

scenario: Your organization is entering a new market with unfamiliar competitors.

options.text: Conduct a detailed market analysis before finalizing strategy.
Rely on existing strategies that worked domestically.
Follow competitors’ tactics to minimize risk.
Launch immediately and adjust later.

scenario: A technological shift could disrupt your main product within a year.

options.text: Develop a roadmap to integrate or outpace the new technology.
Wait until customers demand the change.
Focus on short-term profits before adapting.
Ignore the shift; it's just a trend.

scenario: Your team delivers projects on time but struggles with innovation.

options.text: Set aside time for creative experimentation within sprints.
Keep focus strictly on delivery speed.
Hire new employees specifically for innovation.
Let team members innovate on personal time only.

scenario: Leadership asks you to prepare a five-year growth plan.

options.text: Analyze trends, risks, and set measurable milestones.
Repurpose last year’s plan with updated figures.
Focus only on next year’s targets.
Wait for corporate strategy to guide your plan.

scenario: A partner company proposes a collaboration outside your usual domain.

options.text: Evaluate long-term potential and strategic alignment first.
Reject immediately; it's too risky.
Accept quickly to explore opportunities.
Defer the decision indefinitely.

scenario: An upcoming policy change may affect your industry’s regulations.

options.text: Study implications early and plan compliance strategies.
Wait until the policy is enforced before acting.
Assign responsibility to legal without review.
Ignore; policies rarely impact operations directly.

scenario: You must decide whether to expand the product line or improve existing services.

options.text: Use data to evaluate market potential and scalability.
Base the decision purely on team preference.
Follow what competitors are doing.
Avoid expanding to minimize risks.

scenario: Customer feedback indicates new trends that conflict with your current roadmap.

options.text: Reassess the roadmap to align with evolving user needs.
Stick to the plan; changing direction is costly.
Delay updates until more data confirms the trend.
Disregard feedback; it's anecdotal.

scenario: A competitor starts adopting AI to enhance decision processes.

options.text: Explore AI adoption through a pilot initiative.
Wait to see results before investing.
Ignore the move; AI is just a buzzword.
Focus on marketing to offset the lack of AI tools.

scenario: Your company must choose between a local partnership and global expansion.

options.text: Conduct comparative analysis of long-term gains and risks.
Choose global expansion for visibility.
Stay local to minimize financial risk.
Postpone the decision until next year.

scenario: You’re asked to design a corporate sustainability initiative.

options.text: Develop long-term goals aligning with corporate values and impact.
Replicate another company’s successful model.
Focus only on quick wins for publicity.
Delay planning until leadership prioritizes it.

scenario: Your team’s innovation budget is reduced by 40%.

options.text: Focus remaining funds on the most promising projects.
Distribute funds equally to maintain fairness.
Suspend innovation work until next fiscal year.
Cut small experiments to protect core operations.

scenario: Customer data reveals a gradual shift toward a younger demographic.

options.text: Update strategy to target emerging audience segments.
Keep targeting the existing loyal base.
Delay strategic response until trend stabilizes.
Launch short-term promotions instead of adjusting strategy.

scenario: You must select between automation investment and workforce expansion.

options.text: Model long-term ROI and workforce impact before deciding.
Choose automation for cost savings.
Expand workforce to boost morale.
Delay decision until next budgeting cycle.

scenario: You’re considering a data-driven approach to predict future sales.

options.text: Adopt predictive analytics to forecast trends proactively.
Continue manual tracking methods.
Rely on intuition instead of data.
Wait until another department proves the model.

scenario: An unexpected crisis affects the company’s main revenue stream.

options.text: Develop contingency plans and explore alternative income sources.
Cut expenses and hope for market recovery.
Freeze operations temporarily.
Blame external factors and avoid action.

scenario: A merger opportunity arises that could double company size.

options.text: Conduct due diligence to assess strategic fit and synergy.
Approve quickly to seize the opportunity.
Reject the offer due to potential risks.
Let executives decide without your input.

scenario: The board asks for a 10-year vision for organizational digital transformation.

options.text: Craft a phased plan integrating technology, people, and culture.
Outsource the strategy to an external consultant.
Repurpose existing short-term digital plans.
Delay vision creation until funding approval.

scenario: Data shows your market will shrink in three years due to automation.

options.text: Invest in R&D to create new product lines.
Cut staff to prepare for downturn.
Maintain current operations and hope for stability.
Exit the market immediately.

scenario: Leadership requests metrics to evaluate innovation success.

options.text: Define clear KPIs like ROI, adoption, and time-to-impact.
Measure success only by revenue growth.
Use employee satisfaction surveys instead.
Avoid metrics; innovation can’t be measured.
